skill.name: event-store-design
skill.description: Design and implement event stores for event-sourced systems. Use when building event sourcing infrastructure, choosing event store technologies, or implementing event persistence patterns.
skill.summary: Design and implement event stores for event-sourced systems. Use when building event sourcing infras...

security_audit.summary: No data theft or malicious execution patterns found. Content is documentation with example schemas and code snippets.

content.user_title: Design reliable event stores for event sourcing
content.value_statement: Event sourced systems fail without durable storage. This skill guides you to design schemas, storage choices, and subscriptions.
actual_capabilities: Provide a PostgreSQL schema for append only event storage
Explain event store requirements and architecture patterns
Show a Python async event store implementation example
Demonstrate EventStoreDB client usage and subscriptions
Outline a DynamoDB table and access pattern for events
List best practices and anti patterns for event stores
limitations: Does not deploy or configure infrastructure
Does not provide production security hardening steps
Code examples are templates and require adaptation
Does not cover business domain modeling

use_cases.title: Choose a storage backend
use_cases.description: Compare EventStoreDB, PostgreSQL, Kafka, and DynamoDB for event sourcing needs.

use_cases.title: Design event store schema
use_cases.description: Define tables, indexes, and subscription checkpoints for a new service.

use_cases.title: Review implementation plan
use_cases.description: Validate concurrency, ordering, and scaling choices before delivery.

prompt_templates.title: Event store basics
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain the core requirements of an event store and how streams and global ordering work.

prompt_templates.title: PostgreSQL schema
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide a PostgreSQL schema with tables and indexes for append only event storage and subscriptions.

prompt_templates.title: Python implementation
prompt_templates.prompt: Outline a Python async event store class with append, read stream, and read all methods.

prompt_templates.title: Scale and optimize
prompt_templates.prompt: Recommend strategies for scaling reads, subscriptions, and snapshots in a large event store.

output_examples.input: Design a PostgreSQL event store for an Order service
output: Tables for events, snapshots, and subscription checkpoints
Indexes for stream, global position, and time queries
Guidance on optimistic concurrency and idempotency

best_practices: Use stream identifiers that include aggregate type
Implement optimistic concurrency checks for writes
Store correlation and causation metadata for tracing
anti_patterns: Updating or deleting events after append
Storing large payloads in event data

faq.question: Which platforms are supported?
faq.answer: The guidance applies to any platform that can implement event stores, including Postgres, EventStoreDB, and DynamoDB.

faq.question: What are the main limits?
faq.answer: Examples are templates only and must be adapted for production scale and security.

faq.question: Can it integrate with existing databases?
faq.answer: Yes, it includes patterns for PostgreSQL and DynamoDB event storage.

faq.question: Does it access or store my data?
faq.answer: No, it only provides documentation and code examples.

faq.question: What if my streams are too large?
faq.answer: Use snapshots and read models to reduce replay cost and improve performance.

faq.question: How does it compare to general database advice?
faq.answer: It focuses on event store requirements like ordering, immutability, and subscriptions.
